Dear All,

Whilst we are on the topic of Namban tsuba I have posted two (not so good) images of my Namban tsuba that took a green paper at the first NBTHK Shinsa in the USA mmm maybe 35 years ago.  The obverse (red background) is convex whilst the reverse (green background) is flat.  A polisher visiting once commented "a good one!!".  Early Edo period ca 1670, I believe.

Oh, it's in my folder "Barry Thomas" third one on the first page (sorry, no tiny url.  Something else I have to learn how to do!).  John I think I sent you these images quite some while ago???

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Ron Hartmann 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Thursday, December 07, 2006 7:46 AM
  Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Tsuba help


  Dear John, others - 

  I've posted a photo of the interesting namban tsuba that John had referred to earlier. The motif consists of dragons and catfish, a shrine (with gold jewel peak), breaking waves and vines (?) in sukashi work. This large tsuba (84mm rnd. x 4mm thick) has Tokubetsu Hozon certificate. The poster is in Yahoo photos: http://tinyurl.com/yxt45h
  in a file named: Ron STL Perhaps John wishes to elaborate on this tsuba a bit more? 

  John, I've just received my copy of your book, "The Namban Group of Japanese Sword Guards; Aa Reappraisal" and I'm looking forward to digesting your research findings which make up this publication. Interesting!

  Ron
  STL
